<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_DirCreate_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_DirCreate_Impl(const char *local_path, uint32 access)
{
    struct stat st;
    int32       return_code;

    if (mkdir(local_path, S_IFDIR | S_IRWXU | S_IRWXG | S_IRWXO) < 0)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERROR;

        if (errno == EEXIST)
        {
            /* Success if already exists and is a directory */
            if (stat(local_path, &st) == 0 && S_ISDIR(st.st_mode))
            {
                return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
            }
        }
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>

explanation: No suspicious fragments found. The code contains three controlling expressions: 1) if (mkdir(local_path, S_IFDIR | S_IRWXU | S_IRWXG | S_IRWXO) < 0) — this invokes mkdir and depends on its runtime return value, so it is not invariant; 2) if (errno == EEXIST) — errno is a runtime-modified value set by the failed system call, so this comparison is not an invariant; 3) if (stat(local_path, &st) == 0 && S_ISDIR(st.st_mode)) — both stat() result and st.st_mode are runtime-dependent, so this expression is not invariant. There are no loops or do-while constructs with constant controlling expressions. The use of compile-time constants in the mode flags for mkdir is not a controlling expression and therefore not relevant to Rule 14.3. Consequently, no code fragments in this function require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
